name: ACL
description: Access Control Lists (ACLs) filter network traffic based on criteria like source/destination IP, protocol, and port numbers. ACLs are fundamental for network security and traffic management.
key_topics: Standard ACLs (1-99, 1300-1999): filter by source IP only
Extended ACLs (100-199, 2000-2699): filter by source, destination, protocol, port
Implicit deny all at end of every ACL
ACL placement: standard ACLs close to destination, extended close to source
ACL processing: top-down, stops at first match
common_misconceptions: Training materials often confuse wildcard masks with subnet masks. Cisco documentation emphasizes: wildcard 0 = must match, wildcard 1 = don't care (opposite of subnet masks)
Many resources state to place all ACLs close to source. Cisco config guides clarify: standard ACLs near destination (they only filter source), extended ACLs near source (to drop traffic early)
Third-party books frequently forget the implicit 'deny any' at the end of every ACL. Cisco emphasizes if you don't explicitly permit traffic, the implicit deny will block it
Common error: modifying an ACL by adding lines. In numbered ACLs, you cannot insert lines - you must delete and recreate. Use named ACLs with sequence numbers for editing
